descriptionValue.html:
An application does not sufficiently validate a destination address in URL or HTTP message before sending a response. Exploiting the vulnerability, an attacker can send requests to restricted servers (for example, computers in local networks). This can lead to sensitive data and application source code disclosure, denial of service, etc.

Links

  • CWE-918: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html
descriptionValue.description: An application does not sufficiently validate a destination address in URL or HTTP message before sending a response. Exploiting the vulnerability, an attacker can send requests to restricted servers (for example, computers  in local networks). This can lead to sensitive data and application source code disclosure, denial of service, etc.

descriptionValue.header: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
descriptionValue.description: In jQuery versions greater than or equal to 1.2 and before 3.5.0, passing HTML from untrusted sources - even after sanitizing it - to one of jQuery's DOM manipulation methods (i.e. .html(), .append(), and others) may execute untrusted code. This problem is patched in jQuery 3.5.0.

descriptionValue.header: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
descriptionValue.description: jQuery before 3.4.0, as used in Drupal, Backdrop CMS, and other products, mishandles jQuery.extend(true, {}, ...) because of Object.prototype pollution. If an unsanitized source object contained an enumerable __proto__ property, it could extend the native Object.prototype.
User controlled data in 'new Function()' can result in Server Side Injection (SSI) or Remote Code Execution (RCE).
Wrap element to HTML code.

descriptionValue.header: Sensitive Cookie in HTTPS Session Without ‘Secure’ Attribute
descriptionValue.description: 'Secure' attribute is not set for cookie and it causes browser to use this cookie both for secured connection over HTTPS and unsecured connection over HTTP. An attacker may intercept cookie using man-in-the-middle method. It is recommended to set this attribute for valuable cookie variables and transfer authorization data only over HTTPS.

descriptionValue.html:
A web application can generate SQL queries based on user input data. Because of insufficient data processing, an attacker can inject SQL code and thus modify database query logic. In certain cases, an attacker is able not only read data from a database, but also read arbitrary files, create new files, conduct denial of service, and even get web application source codes, upload and execute malware code.

A vulnerable script example:

                
if (isset($_GET['id'])) {
    try {
        $dbh = new PDO('mysql:dbname=test;host=127.0.0.1', 'root', 'pass');
    } catch (PDOException $e) {
        echo "Connection failed\n";
        exit;
    }
    $stm = $dbh->query("SELECT * FROM users WHERE id=" . $_GET['id']);
    $user = $stm->fetch();
    echo "User name: " . $user['name'] . "\n";
}

An attacker can obtain arbitrary data, for example database version, sending the following line in id parameter: 0+union+select+1,version().

Figure 1. SQL Injection example

Recommendations

We recommend you to convert variables to integer type to protect against SQL Injection attacks.

                
if (isset($_GET['id'])) {
    try {
        $dbh = new PDO('mysql:dbname=test;host=127.0.0.1', 'root', 'pass');
    } catch (PDOException $e) {
        echo "Connection failed\n";
        exit;
    }
    $stm = $dbh->query("SELECT * FROM users WHERE id=" . (int)$_GET['id']);
    $user = $stm->fetch();
    echo "User name: " . $user['name'] . "\n";
}

A good idea is to use parametrized SQL queries instead of simple concatenation of variables and query templates in application code.

                
if (isset($_GET['id'])) {
    try {
        $dbh = new PDO('mysql:dbname=test;host=127.0.0.1', 'root', 'pass');
    } catch (PDOException $e) {
        echo "Connection failed\n";
        exit;
    }
    $stm = $dbh->prepare("SELECT name FROM users WHERE id=?");
    $stm->execute(array($_GET['id']));
    $user = $stm->fetch(PDO::FETCH_ASSOC);
    echo "User name: " . $user['name'] . "\n";
}

It is also required to use the principle of minimal privilege to guarantee that an account aimed to web application interaction with a database has minimal privileges and all other privileges are not available.

Links

  • SQL Injection https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection
  • CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/89.html
descriptionValue.description: The application does not sufficiently validate user input that allows an attacker to manipulate SQL query logic by injecting arbitrary SQL operators.
Adds a string inside HTML tag.

descriptionValue.html:
An application does not sufficiently validate user input that allows an attacker to create a malformed log file or inject an arbitrary code.

A web application can generate log file entities based on user input data. Because of insufficient data processing, an attacker can inject dividing characters and therefore create a malformed log file entity, making it impossible to automatically process this file. Also, an attacker can inject malware and use it for further attacks.

Please fins the vulnerable script example below:

                
$result = $authService->authenticate($login, $password);

if (!$result->isValid()) {
    $log->write("Authentication failed for user '$login'");
}

Recommendations

We recommend you process log file data to delete or escape formaztting characters.

Links

  • Log Forging https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Log_Forging
  • CWE-117: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/117.html
descriptionValue.description: An application does not sufficiently validate user input that allows an attacker to create a specially malformed item for a log file or inject malware into it.
An unprotected transport used for data transferring on application level makes it possible to conduct a "man-in-the-middle" attack.
User controlled data in 'setTimeout()' can result in Server Side Injection (SSI) or Remote Code Execution (RCE).
An information exposure is the intentional or unintentional disclosure of information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

Vulnerable hashing functions in your application can lead to predictable hash collisions or hash reverse attacks. Cryptographic hashing guarantee that hash collisions are unlikely, and hash reversing is difficult to conduct.
JQuery use strictly prohibited

descriptionValue.header: Information Exposure Through Static Content Or String Literals
descriptionValue.description: HTML documents or string constants may contain sensitive information. The presence of such information in these places must be considered.
Poor Error Handling: Empty Default Exception Handler. Ignoring an exception can cause the program to overlook unexpected states and conditions.
Function that replaces element by new.

descriptionValue.html:
Web application's components and their versions are exposed to the users and can be enumerated . Such information can help hackers in choosing an appropriate attack vector.

Fingerprinting can be performed not only through search of software's name/version, but also via analysis of its response to specific requests, presence of specific files, directories and etc.

Example of HTTP-response, disclosing information about the software version:

                
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 1994 08:12:31 GMT
Server: Apache/2.2.17 (Win32) PHP/5.3.5
Content-Type: text/html

Recommendations

It is recommended to masquerade the software where possible, so that information on software names, versions, plugins and etc. is hidden from the users.

Links

  • Fingerprinting http://projects.webappsec.org/w/page/13246925/Fingerprinting
  • CWE-205: Information Exposure Through Behavioral Discrepancy http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/205.html
descriptionValue.description: Fingerprinting is a technique aimed at collecting as much information as possible about a web application and its components. Hacker can later use such information to develop more targeted and efficient attacks.

descriptionValue.html:
If a resource privileges do not meet the principle of minimal privileges, information disclosure or resource content modification is possible. Exploiting the vulnerability, an attacker can execute arbitrary code, cause denial of service, etc.

A vulnerable script example:

                
if (isset($_GET['page'], $_POST['content'])) {
    $filename = 'pages/' . $_GET['page'];
    $fp = fopen($filename, 'w');
    fwrite($fp, $_POST['content']);
    fclose($fp);
}

An attacker can use traversal methods to modify a file localed outside pages folder.

Recommendations

We recommend you to conduct validation by regular expressions that restrict arbitrary file creation, or check files by white lists. We also recommend you to execute application code in isolated environment.

Links

  • CWE-73: External Control of File Name or Path http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/73.html
descriptionValue.description: If a resource privileges do not meet the principle of minimal privileges, information disclosure or resource content modification is possible. Exploiting the vulnerability, an attacker can execute arbitrary code, cause denial of service, etc.

descriptionValue.header: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
descriptionValue.description: jQuery before 1.9.0 is vulnerable to Cross-site Scripting (XSS) attacks. The jQuery(strInput) function does not differentiate selectors from HTML in a reliable fashion. In vulnerable versions, jQuery determined whether the input was HTML by looking for the '<' character anywhere in the string, giving attackers more flexibility when attempting to construct a malicious payload. In fixed versions, jQuery only deems the input to be HTML if it explicitly starts with the '<' character, limiting exploitability only to attackers who can control the beginning of a string, which is far less common.

descriptionValue.header: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
descriptionValue.description: In jQuery versions greater than or equal to 1.0.3 and before 3.5.0, passing HTML containing <option> elements from untrusted sources - even after sanitizing it - to one of jQuery's DOM manipulation methods (i.e. .html(), .append(), and others) may execute untrusted code. This problem is patched in jQuery 3.5.0.

descriptionValue.header: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
descriptionValue.description: jQuery before 3.0.0 is vulnerable to Cross-site Scripting (XSS) attacks when a cross-domain Ajax request is performed without the dataType option, causing text/javascript responses to be executed.

descriptionValue.html:
A web application is vulnerable if it places data from an untrusted source without sufficient processing into a web server response. An attacker can conduct this attack to execute a malware script in a target domain's context. As a rule, the malware code sends user sensitive data to the attacker, for example user session ID.

A vulnerable script example:

                
if (isset($_GET['name'])) {
    echo "{$_GET['name']}!\n";
}

An attacker can make a user to go to this link http://test.loc/test.php?name=%3Cscript%3Ealert. The following code is injected into web server response: <script>alert('XSS')<script>. The results are given on the figure:

Figure 1. An attack example

Web application can be vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting not only in HTTP response data displaying, but also in displaying results of database queries, file content, etc.

Recommendations

To eliminate the vulnerability, escape special characters depending on the data context.

Links

  • Cross-site Scripting (XSS) https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)
  • CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/79.html
descriptionValue.description: The application does not sufficiently validate user input that allows attackers to to execute arbitrary code in the context of victim's browser bypassing the Same Origin Policy (SOP).

descriptionValue.html:
A web application is vulnerable if it allows users to upload files without extension and content validation. Exploiting the vulnerability, an attacker can conduct attacks against clients (Content Spoofing, Cross-Site Scripting), execute arbitrary code, etc.

A vulnerable script example:

                
$uploaddir = 'uploads/'; // Relative path under webroot
$uploadfile = $uploaddir . basename($_FILES['userfile']['name']);
if (move_uploaded_file($_FILES['userfile']['tmp_name'], $uploadfile)) {
    echo "File is valid, and was successfully uploaded.\n";
} else {
    echo "File uploading failed.\n";
}

Using HTML form, an attacker can load arbitrary files to uploads server folder that is available from outside.

                
<form name="upload" action="upload.php" method="POST" ENCTYPE="multipart/formdata">
    Select the file to upload: <input type="file" name="userfile">
    <input type="submit" name="upload" value="upload">
</form>

Also, file content is not validated, that allows attackers to upload shell.php PHP script with the following content:

                
system($_GET['command']);

and execute system commands directly calling the file:

                
http://server/shell.php?command = any Unix_shell_command

Recommendations

We recommend you to validate file extensions via regular expressions.

Links

  • Unrestricted File Upload : https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Unrestricted_File_Upload
descriptionValue.description: Unrestricted File Upload vulnerability allows attackers to upload files with arbitrary contents and/or extension to a target server and execute  arbitrary code or conduct attacks against clients (Content Spoofing, Cross-Site Scripting, etc.). We recommend you to use regular expressions for file extension checks.
Debug pages or messages, error descriptions, stack tracing, etc. in productive systems allows attackers to obtain information about application internals that is useful for conducting attacks.
Unsafe functions add HTML code for DOM structure.

descriptionValue.html:
A web application can use user input to generate a path to a modifying file and its content. Exploiting the vulnerability, an attacker can execute arbitrary code, cause denial of service, etc.

A vulnerable script example:

                
if (isset($_GET['name'], $_POST['content'])) {
    $filename = 'config/' . $_GET['name'];
    $content = $_POST['content'];

    if (file_exists($filename))
        file_put_contents($filename, $content);
}

An attacker can use traversal methods to modify a file localed outside config folder.

Recommendations

We recommend you to conduct validation by regular expressions that restrict arbitrary file modification, or check files by white lists. We also recommend you to execute application code in isolated environment.

Links

  • CWE-73: External Control of File Name or Path http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/73.html
descriptionValue.description: Arbitrary Files Modification is a vulnerability that allows an attacker to modify the contents of server files. It may result in denial of service, application logic bypass, arbitrary code execution, etc.

descriptionValue.header: Sensitive Cookie in HTTPS Session Without ‘Httponly’ Attribute
descriptionValue.description: "Httponly" attribute is not set for cookie and it causes client-side script has ability to extract cookie.  An attacker may intercept cookie using XSS attack. It is recommended to set this attribute for valuable cookie variables. Cookie with this attribute cannot be accessed through client side script.

descriptionValue.html: Hardcoded or empty passwords could lead to system compromising that is hard to eliminate.
descriptionValue.description: Hardcoded or empty passwords could lead to system compromising that is hard to eliminate.

The code uses a variable that has not been initialized, leading to unpredictable or unintended results. In some languages such as C and C++, stack variables are not initialized by default. They generally contain junk data with the contents of stack memory before the function was invoked. An attacker can sometimes control or read these contents. In other languages or conditions, a variable that is not explicitly initialized can be given a default value that has security implications, depending on the logic of the program. The presence of an uninitialized variable can sometimes indicate a typographic error in the code.
Selector vulnerability, adding HTML code in page's DOM structure.
